question: 1 (b) i
sols_html:
To do this problem, we rearrange the equation to isolate \(y\) and then take the derivative of \(y\) with respect to \(x\):

\[\begin{aligned} e^{2x} + y(1 - x) = 1 \\ \rightarrow \quad y = \frac{1 - e^{2x}}{1 - x}\end{aligned}\]

Using the quotient rule, we evaluate \(dy/dx\) and we are done:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{(-2e^{2x})(1-x) - (-1)(1 - e^{2x})}{(1-x)^{2}} = \frac{-3e^{2x}+2xe^{2x}+1}{(x-1)^{2}}.\end{aligned}\]

Hence, at x = 0 we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dx}(0) = \frac{-3e^{0}+0+1}{(-1)^2} = -2\end{aligned}\]

We can also use implicit differentiation. By differentiating with respect to x we obtain:

\[\begin{aligned} 2e^{2x} + \frac{dy}{dx}(1-x) + y(-1) = 0\end{aligned}\]

(Watch out for the product rule on the term y(1-x))

The difference is that we need to know the value of y when x = 0, but if we plug that in the original equation we obtain

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle e^0 + y(1-0) = 1\end{aligned}\]

and so we have that y = 0. We use this in what we obtained by differentiating implicitly:

\[\begin{aligned} 2e^0 + \frac{dy}{dx} + 0 = 0\end{aligned}\]

and so we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dx}(0) = -2\end{aligned}\]

We can also use implicit differentiation. By differentiating with
respect to \emph{x} we obtain:

\begin{align*}
2e^{2x} + \frac{dy}{dx}(1-x) + y(-1) = 0
\end{align*} (Watch out for the product
rule on the term \emph{y}(1-\emph{x}))

The difference is that we need to know the value of \emph{y} when
\emph{x} = 0, but if we plug that in the original equation we obtain

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
e^0 + y(1-0) = 1
\end{align*} and so we have that \emph{y} = 0. We use this in what
we obtained by differentiating implicitly:

\begin{align*}
2e^0 + \frac{dy}{dx} + 0 = 0
\end{align*} and so we have that

\begin{align*}
\frac{dy}{dx}(0) = -2
\end{align*}
